arch:property.oc:show_val: This is the ashy soil area that was discovered upon the excavation of L166. It is in the southeast corner of the trench against the baulk and the north side of the wall. Its border with L168 is fairly undefined and thus its finds might be mixed with the abutting surfaces. Additionally, when L166 was begun, this ashy soil was noticed immediately, but it was not made into its own locus until L166 had finished excavation because we wanted to make sure that it really was diffferent. Thus some of its finds will be mixed in with L166 bags, and since these two are so closely connected this is ok. They are likely contemporary with each other. This locus is likely a firepit, either from this area or mixed in from the bailk. Its ash is also bleeding into the surfaces that abutt it; the borders between this and any locus that it touches except the wall are very indistinct, meaning that some finds could again be mixed. It produced a lot of burned pottery and bone and some lithic.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area E / Trench 2 / Locus 167 (Locus)
